provenance:
Edwin Thorne, AAG, New York, 27 January, 1893, no. 63.[1] William Shaus, New York. Crocker Collection, San Francisco, California until 1969. (Sloan and Roman, Inc., New York, New York); sold to MIA in 1970.

[1] See Ackerman, 1986, no. 349.
text: Frame: Gift of funds from the Paintings Council Schooled at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts and honored by the French Salon, Jean-Léon Gérôme was a prolific and popular artist. Like Delacroix, he traveled extensively in North Africa and the Middle East. The Carpet Merchant depicts the Court of the Rug Market in Cairo, which Gérôme had visited in 1885. The inscription on this period frame, "There is no victor save God," is from the Islamic Nasrid dynasty that ruled southern Spain from 1230–1492.
title: Frame, formerly on Gerome "The Carpet Merchant"
